global agriculture is already a trifrification.
there's one fork of the trifrification, which are all these folks that are, you know, in the lower resource nations working, you know, less than five acre plots.
another part of the trifrification, which are these massive, you know, 5,000, 10,000 acre plus, you know, like monocrops that we use for corn, soy, wheat.
that is almost fully automated anyhow, that's just a huge tractor and one dude, where sometimes it's an automated system and doing, you know, 10,000 acres or more in a monocrop.
the third trifrification are the folks that are farmers that are working between like one acre and 2,000 acres.
we call them specialty crops. So like things like artichokes and garlic and whatever.
in practice, it's like that's actually most of the food we eat in the, in the developed world.
in the developing world, it is the sub-fibaker farmers that are doing most of the grueling.
the trifrification is also not accidental. There are both human and economic factors that make those the thing that we've gone with so far.
